Hoc edictum necessarium est, quoniam magna utilitas absentium vertitur, ne indefensi rerum possessionem aut venditionem patiantur, vel pignoris distractionem, vel poenae committendae actionem, vel iniuria rem suam amittant’ Dig. 3. 5. 3. 1. To constitute tbe relation it is necessary that the business in which the gestor interseres should be some one's else and not his own, Dig. ib. 6. 4 (no stress should be laid on ‘absentes' in our text), and that his interserence should not be grounded on any office or express mandate on which he can sue; if there hasbeen a mandatum, but no actio mandati lies, he can sue as negotiorum gestor, Dig. ib. 19 2. His duties are in substance the same as those ol a commissioned agent, lor which see on Tit 26. 8 supr. Those os the dominus negotii are mainly to indemnisy the gestor against all reasonable expenses, with interest, and to guarantee him against all liabilities which he has in· curred on his behalf, Dig. ib. 10.pr.; but the gestor could not enlorce these duties by actio contraria, unless

(1) The dominus had not prohibited his interserence, eon 2. 19. 24.

(2) His own intention in undertaking the business had been to lay the other under a legal obligation, ‘negotia eo animo gerit, ut aliquem sibi obliget' Dig. 10. 51415 so that il his object was his own sole ad· vantage he could sue the dominus only so sar as the latter had derived material benefit from his gestio, Dig. 5 5. 6. 3. Il he unwittingly in· tersered with another person's business (e. g. as being a bona fide possessor) he could assert his claim to compensation for reasonable outlay only by exceptio, unless what he ‘possessed' was an hereditas, in which case he had an action, Dig. ib. 49; ιο. 3. 14. 1 ; ib. 29. pr.

(3) The state of the dominus' affairs was such that, except sor the foreign intervention, he would be seriously prejudiced‚ Dig. 44 7. 5. pr. ; il this is s0, the gestor can recover even though the anticipated benefit as a lact is not realized, or, as it is sometimes put, the negotia need not have been utiliter gesta, it is enough il they were utiliter coepta, Dig. 15. 3. 10. 1 ; ib. 12. 2. Ii the gestio was not thus warranted, but the gestor’s object was to secure a great advantage for the dominus, be could recover only so far as the advantage actually went, Dig. ib. 11 ς ib. 43.

Subsequent ratification ol the gestio hythe dominus transforms the relation into mandatum according to Ulpian in Dig.42. 1. 60, while Scaevola in Dig. 3 5. 9 says that its character remains unaltered. The solution oi the antinomy is probably that alter ratification the gestor can treat the dominus as mandator, but the latter (ratification being merely a unitateral act) is not entitled to treat the former as mandatarius.
